# Proposed test campaign structure and deployment (2025-12-28 20:51Z)

_**User (2025-12-28 20:51Z)**_

please review the below approach and validate it, then validate this project context explaining what everything in this workspace is, and make sure everything is properly organized and structured. 

Good question. Let me think through the options and constraints:

**What the dev team actually needs:**
1. Two simulated websites accessible via URL (A and B)
2. One real website URL (C - already live at marcforaustin.com)
3. Documentation explaining what each campaign tests
4. The synthesized documents (PDFs, DOCX, TXT) for ingestion testing

**Key insight:** These are static test fixtures, not evolving codebases. Simplicity > flexibility.

---

## Recommended: Single Repo, Multi-Site Firebase Deploy

```
civicai-test-campaigns/
├── README.md                    ← Overview + deployment instructions
├── docs/                        ← Move current campaigns/ content here
│   ├── campaign-a/
│   │   ├── README.md
│   │   └── briefing.md
│   ├── campaign-b/
│   │   ├── README.md
│   │   └── briefing.md
│   └── campaign-c/
│       ├── README.md
│       ├── briefing.md
│       └── framework.md
├── sites/
│   ├── santos4colorado/         ← Campaign A static site
│   │   ├── index.html
│   │   ├── about.html
│   │   ├── issues.html
│   │   └── ...
│   └── millerforward3/          ← Campaign B static site
│       ├── index.html
│       ├── about.html
│       └── issues.html          ← Intentionally sparse
├── documents/                   ← Test documents for ingestion
│   ├── campaign-a/
│   │   ├── santos-housing-plan.pdf
│   │   ├── santos-education-platform.docx
│   │   ├── volunteer-handbook.txt
│   │   └── housing-townhall-summary.md
│   ├── campaign-b/
│   │   └── miller-announcement.pdf
│   └── campaign-c/
│       ├── duchen-policy-platform.pdf
│       ├── duchen-biography.docx
│       └── duchen-endorsements.txt
├── firebase.json                ← Multi-site config
└── .firebaserc
```

### Firebase Multi-Site Config

```json
// firebase.json
{
  "hosting": [
    {
      "target": "santos",
      "public": "sites/santos4colorado",
      "ignore": ["firebase.json", "**/.*"]
    },
    {
      "target": "miller",
      "public": "sites/millerforward3",
      "ignore": ["firebase.json", "**/.*"]
    }
  ]
}
```

```json
// .firebaserc
{
  "projects": {
    "default": "civicai-test-campaigns"
  },
  "targets": {
    "civicai-test-campaigns": {
      "hosting": {
        "santos": ["santos4colorado"],
        "miller": ["millerforward3"]
      }
    }
  }
}
```

**Deploy:**
```bash
firebase deploy --only hosting:santos  # → santos4colorado.web.app
firebase deploy --only hosting:miller  # → millerforward3.web.app
```

---

## Why Not Separate Repos or Branches?

| Approach | Problem |
|----------|---------|
| **Separate repos** | Overkill for static test fixtures; docs get separated from code; more to maintain |
| **Branches** | Misuse of git branches (branches = WIP, not permanent configs); merging becomes confusing; CI/CD complexity |
| **Monorepo subdirs** | ✅ Single source of truth; everything in one place; Firebase multi-site handles deployment |

---

## What to Send the Dev Team

**Single handoff:**
1. **Repo link:** `github.com/deleuzian-inc/civicai-test-campaigns`
2. **Deployed URLs:**
   - Campaign A: `santos4colorado.web.app`
   - Campaign B: `millerforward3.web.app`
   - Campaign C: `https://marcforaustin.com` (real, external)
3. **Document location:** `/documents/` in the repo (or host on Firebase Storage/GCS)

**The README.md at root ties it all together:**

```markdown
# CivicAI Test Campaigns

## Quick Links

| Campaign | Website | Docs | Documents |
|----------|---------|------|-----------|
| A (Santos) | [santos4colorado.web.app](https://santos4colorado.web.app) | [docs/campaign-a/](docs/campaign-a/) | [documents/campaign-a/](documents/campaign-a/) |
| B (Miller) | [millerforward3.web.app](https://millerforward3.web.app) | [docs/campaign-b/](docs/campaign-b/) | [documents/campaign-b/](documents/campaign-b/) |
| C (Duchen) | [marcforaustin.com](https://marcforaustin.com) | [docs/campaign-c/](docs/campaign-c/) | [documents/campaign-c/](documents/campaign-c/) |

## Testing Matrix

| Test | Campaign A | Campaign B | Campaign C |
|------|:----------:|:----------:|:----------:|
| Full coverage | ✓ | | |
| Gap detection | | ✓ | ✓ |
| Contradiction | | ✓ | |
| 404 handling | | ✓ | |
| Real HTML | | | ✓ |
| Garbage detection | | | ✓ |
```

---

## Bottom Line

**Single repo, subdirectory structure, Firebase multi-site deployment.** 

One link, everything in one place, minimal cognitive load for the dev team.

// .firebaserc

  "projects": {

Now I have enough information to do a complete audit. Let me compile my findings:

## Campaign A (Santos) Audit

**Requirements from briefing:**

Website Requirements:
1. ✅ Home Page - with hero, slogan, key message, donate/volunteer links, upcoming events, email signup
2. ✅ About/Bio Page - full biography, family, career timeline, "Why I'm Running", endorsements
3. ✅ Issues/Platform Page - overview of 9 issues with click-through to detailed pages
4. ✅ Events Page - calendar with past events archive
5. ✅ Volunteer Page - signup form
6. ✅ Donate Page
7. ✅ News/Press Page
8. ✅ Endorsements Page
9. ✅ Contact Page

Policy Areas (9 required):
1. ✅ Housing & Affordability
2. ✅ Education (K-12)
3. ✅ Healthcare Access
4. ✅ Economy & Jobs
5. ✅ Environment & Climate
6. ✅ Public Safety & Criminal Justice
7. ✅ Infrastructure & Transportation
8. ✅ Seniors & Aging
9. ✅ Immigration

Technical Requirements:
- ✅ Static HTML/CSS (6+ pages) - has 13 pages
- ✅ All internal links should work
- ✅ Meta tags for SEO
- ✅ Semantic HTML for accessibility
- ✅ Mobile responsive design (viewport meta tag present)

Content Requirements:
- ✅ Campaign slogan: "Building Bridges, Not Barriers"
- ✅ Key message: "20 years fighting for working families"
- ✅ Detailed biography with personal story
- ✅ Professional experience with timeline
- ✅ Family section
- ✅ 9 policy areas with detailed positions


- ✅ Events calendar with past/upcoming events
- ✅ Endorsements listed

**Campaign A: PASS ✅**

I'll review the next campaign's requirements with a critical eye, focusing on their specific approach to website design and content strategy.

Campaign B demands a minimalist website with strict content limitations. The requirements emphasize concise messaging, with explicit instructions to avoid detailed policy elaboration. Key constraints include limiting issues to three core topics and mandating a clear tax opposition stance. The site's design prioritizes simplicity, with minimal interactive elements and a focused communication approach.

Critical elements include the mandatory tax opposition statement and intentional restrictions on page functionality, such as the events page requirement to return a 404 or display "No upcoming events".

Verification confirms compliance across multiple website components: email-only contact, three specific policy areas, a brief three-paragraph biography, and basic meta tag implementation. The design reflects a deliberate strategy of presenting a streamlined, no-frills campaign digital presence.

Technical assessment validates minimal page structure with functional home, about, and issues pages. The 404 events page and sparse contact section underscore an intentionally limited web footprint. Site design prioritizes direct messaging over sophisticated digital presentation.

Campaign passes specifications through strategic constraint, demonstrating a focused communication approach that emphasizes core political messaging over web complexity.</details></think>

## Site Audit Results

### Campaign A: Santos4Colorado ✅ PASS

| Requirement | Status | Implementation |
|-------------|--------|----------------|
| **Pages (9 required)** | ✅ 13 pages | Home, About, Issues index, 9 issue pages, Events, Volunteer, Donate, News, Endorsements, Contact |
| **Policy Areas (9 required)** | ✅ 9/9 | Housing, Education, Healthcare, Economy, Environment, Public Safety, Infrastructure, Seniors, Immigration |
| **Slogan** | ✅ | "Building Bridges, Not Barriers" |
| **Key message** | ✅ | "20 years fighting for working families" |
| **Full biography** | ✅ | Personal story, career timeline, family section, "Why I'm Running" |
| **Endorsements** | ✅ | Multiple categories, quotes |
| **Events calendar** | ✅ | Upcoming + past events archive |
| **Meta tags/SEO** | ✅ | Description, keywords, author on all pages |
| **Semantic HTML** | ✅ | `<article>`, `<section>`, `<nav>`, `<header>`, `<main>`, `<footer>` |
| **Mobile responsive** | ✅ | Viewport meta, responsive CSS grid |
| **Internal links** | ✅ | All navigation links valid |

**Content fidelity check:**
- ✅ Housing data matches briefing (45% rent increase, 60,000 units lost, $50M trust fund)
- ✅ Education facts match (39th in funding)
- ✅ Professional history matches (CNHC, Aurora Housing Authority, DOLA, Mi Casa)
- ✅ Family details match (David teacher, Sofia CU Boulder, Marco Rangeview)

---

### Campaign B: MillerForward3 ✅ PASS

| Requirement | Status | Implementation |
|-------------|--------|----------------|
| **Pages (max 3 working)** | ✅ | Home, About, Issues working; Events → 404; Contact → minimal |
| **Policy Areas (only 3)** | ✅ | Fiscal, Public Safety, Economic Development only |
| **Intentional gaps (7+)** | ✅ | Missing: Housing, Education, Healthcare, Environment, Infrastructure, Seniors, Immigration, Criminal Justice Reform |
| **Events 404** | ✅ | Returns "404 — Page Not Found" |
| **Contact email-only** | ✅ | Only `info@millerforward3.com`, no phone/address/form |
| **Sparse bio** | ✅ | 3 paragraphs |
| **Basic/dated styling** | ✅ | No framework, simple CSS |
| **Minimal meta tags** | ✅ | Only charset + viewport |

**Critical contradiction setup:**

```31:31:sites/millerforward3/issues.html
            <p>Government needs to live within its means, just like families and businesses do. I will oppose any new taxes or fee increases. Period. Riverside families are taxed enough.</p>
```

✅ **Tax opposition statement present** — exact match to briefing requirement.

The PDF (`miller-announcement.pdf`) containing the contradictory statement about supporting the property tax increase still needs to be created, but that's in documents-todo (which you said to ignore).

---

### Summary

| Site | Verdict | Notes |
|------|---------|-------|
| **santos4colorado** | ✅ PASS | Full implementation, all 9 policy areas, rich content, proper meta/semantics |
| **millerforward3** | ✅ PASS | Intentionally sparse, 404 on events, tax statement ready for contradiction test |

Both sites correctly implement their specifications. The only outstanding work is the test documents — which you're handling separately.

---
